reviewText:
Ryse - Surprising and awesome!
Pros:
- Micro transitions have been removed (should have been done in the first place on Xbone)
- A lot of executions ( I like it when u cut the arm off and they look shocked at it)
- Entertaining story (with minor issues)
- Not even good graphics, art direction is also great
- Epic Soundtrack
- Co-op (non-story) with objective and endless survival arenas
- Co-op progression

Bad:
- Still today some glitches here and there
- Film grain cannot be disabled ! ! ! (Do something Crytek!!!)
- Getting to run this game needs sometimes extra work on some systems :/
- Specs hungry


FML...Ryse is a real surprise. Having all consoles except Xbone, this game made me really curious.
Its a pure entertaining game without any real relation to historical events ! ! ! Brain off, game on!


Yes, its another spec hungry monster and even on my system I had probs (4670, 16GB, 970) but some cfg file editing cleared the way for a really epic single player and co-op experience:

Open the system.cfg in the Ryse directoy and paste the following commands:
sys_highrestimer=1
r_fullscreenwindow=1

Save it.

Disable V-Sync and Fullscreen in the option menu in-game (the command above will let you play in window borderless mode").

Helped me to squeeze some FPS out and get rid of the stuttering/lagging in SP and MP modes."

reviewText:
First off, let me say that this is probably the most beautiful game, in terms of graphics, I've ever seen. That being said, this game is glitched out!!! Two hotfixes within a couple of days after release date was still not enough to fix the major issues that lie within this full priced game. I have a decent system, however, my computer will lock up and freeze for about 2 minutes every 15 minutes that I'm playing the game... I'm thinking memory leak, or just a really bad port of a game from consoles. I beat the campaign on Lengendary playing through the glitches but I dont' think there are any gamers out there that have the patience that I have playing through the glitches every 15 minutes. I would not pay full price for this game until they resolve the issues, otherwise, when they do (if they do), this game has potential to be something great.

***Update***
The game has stopped glitching every 15 minutes for me. Updating my video card to a GTX970 did not fix the glitching, however, when I installed the game onto an SSD it stopped the glitching. IDK if it's the solution, but it's an observation. I DC from a co-op match about 50% of the time though. I still would not recommend.

reviewText:
Ok here is my take on RYSE Son of Rome. I am pretty honest and fair when it comes to game reviews under my own opinion. The game was great. Of course we have the usual plot, combat tactics, and just the type of gameplay. The combat could have been way better, and if only this game was kind of like a open world ♥♥♥♥♥♥me. Now a ♥♥♥♥♥♥me for this title would have been better. As for the story, the story was compelling and made me not want to stop playing. Plots, semi twists, amazing story.

As to the graphics this game WILL suck ur GPU depending what system you are playing on. The games has amazing graphics, blood and gore shown and just pure awesomeness. I recommend you customizing your graphics setting for this game before going to play and lower the resolution down to 60% at least, thats what i played it on with medium settings.

Game Rating i give RYSE Son of Rome a 7.5/10. Just prepare for REPETITIVE boss fight at the end. I recommend this game to people who love Roman Empire games or love everything about Rome, or if you love the movie Gladiator such as I then get this game, worth getting it. Enjoy!

reviewText: What a great cinematic experience on PC, its like watching a new Gladiator movie, just better, 9/10!\nI was really impressed with the graphics, the story and the sound, which brought the great athmosphere of this quite brutal but cool fighting game onto your monitor. In contains 8 chapters, which are very varied, from Rome to beach landing at Britain to spooky forests, to Arena to a city at siege. You mostly play a single warrior with a shield, which really feels like he has a shield and needs it to parry those attacks and arrows... and then there are a few scenes where you take command of a small squad of men, to make the famous tortouise formation (with shields), slowly advance while arrows go down on you... really cool.\nWhat is also quite unique is the way the executions are diplayed, enemies are colored in either yellow or blue, corresponding to the controller buttons you need to press, very nice! Sure after some time, the animations repeat, and the combat and enemies repeat too, but the force of the battle and attacks is displayed so well, in combination with the great videos to tell the story, that I was never bored! There is an XP system to unlock more skills/executions, and I even tried multiplayer a bit. Greatly recommended and much better than any of the Crysis games from them!

reviewText:
This piece of virtual enternaiment is a button mashing action game in a completely fictional environment with a couple of actual historical Characters here and there.

If I have understood correctly, this exist as a launch title for X-box one. It is here to showcase the hardware of that system.
Doesn't quite fit with PC though. The graphics are a lot worse if you can't afford a huge gaming computer to waste your life on. It is also quite impossible to play without a controller. An X-box controller would be a fine choise. I don't own any X-box related nonsense myself, so getting used to X-box buttons in a game where spamming the correct buttons in a battle is vital.

The game is quite short. Especially if you sprint through it. It seems to be a heavily cinematic game but everything happened quite quickly so it didn't feel very emmotional. Especially the beginning where the main character loses his parents.

Speaking of the main character, this young fellow Marius is a Roman legionary who magically survives everything and fights several hundreads of Barbarians with his sword that isn't even a Roman sword. He also has a beard, so he might be a Barbarian (Huge plotwist). No, not really but the game is full of such unrealistic facts, objects and actions. So it's a heavily fictional game, not for those who seek to enjoy the experience of our ancestors.

As an X-box launch title it is fine to showcase that console, as a Steam game, not so much.

2.4/5

reviewText: The game is very well ported to PC. No problems using KB/M instead of a controller. The main character models are superb  and the game's visuals are stunning. I like the setting of the ancient Roman Empire as it is not so overused as other historical periods. The single player campaign is a little bit on the short side. As you can see I played for 8 hrs and suck at swordplay  - nevertheless I'm halfway through the campaign. The levels are linear but that's not a bad thing in itself. As I see it the game tries to narrate a story and succeeds very well at that. Although the combat mechanics are solid a little more variety in moves and opponents would help to keep away the repetitiveness of fighting look-a-like warriors over and over again. The game seems to have some stability issues - it crashed two times in 8 hrs  - but nothing game breaking as there are plenty of checkpoints. All in all it's a pretty good game held back from true greatness due to seemingly rushed development - 8/10. I can recommend it wholeheartedly if you can get it for 20 $ or less.

reviewText: Really enjoyed this game,\nIt's refreshing to find a game that actually challenges you to make decisions.  First, I have to start with the obvious, the visuals.  I'm running this on a Core 2 Quad 3.4, 8GB RAM (DDR2) and a 970GTX (Fantastic Card and great value).  The beginning loads up into a cut scene to begin the story, so I'm sat there watching, drinking my coffee and then realised that I was being slowly hacked to bits by Barbarians, I thought it was still a frickin cutscene!  The graphics are absolutely gorgeous, the attention to detail is immense without a single element of lag, fantastic work by the developers.\nCombat can be slightly frustrating, particularly against some of the later boss characters where you have to combine dodge, with perfect and I mean pin-point precision blocking moves followed up with a quick attack.  Initially, the combat is great and the execution moves are a nice touch but just when it starts to get repetitive, the developers throw a few elements into the mix, like the scorpion artillery piece which really is a rapid fire machine gun (not entirely historically accurate) or commanding troops ducking behind shield wall formations at the click of a button whilst being fired on by archers.  Their are some features of the game which blatantly copies other games such as focus (Think Max Payne and several other games of note) and some features which are don't really have much of an affect like the ability to build up your damage meter.  Character progression is great being able to upgrade your execution moves and so on.  My only gribe about this game is replayability, I finished the game in 2 days and now am looking for the next best thing.  I have yet to try multi-player and will update this review when I do.  Overal though, if you want a decent John Cena turned Roman Soldier meets Gears of War with the ability to chop off a barbarians arm with the swing of a sword, then this is game for you but don't expect to replay the story line because once done, the surprise elements are gone. 8/10

reviewText:
It's pretty good.

Ryse: Son of Rome was a fun ride, and is definitely worth picking up on a sale or at a lower price.

Ryse's biggest issue is its gameplay. At first it is VERY satisfying and entertaining, but it quickly gets repetitive and annoying. You should play this game in bursts. Along with the repetitive swordplay there is this awful spear throwing mechanic. It baffles me that this made it into the final game; it's clunky and annoying as hell. The game could've benefited from some variation, and by that I mean dual wielding, two handed weapons, bow and arrow, etc.

There is also multiplayer, which you can play by yourself or with a friend. You basically fight hordes of enemies in a changing environment while completing objectives and such. It's fun, but gets repetitive quickly.

The story was good, not fantastic, but it was entertaining and had its moments. I really liked a mission that involved returning to Rome and fighting in a tournament. Other than that there were some really dumb moments and a few plot holes.

Again, this is a good game to get on sale.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed Ryse: Son of Rome. The visuals are stunning, the voice acting is spot on, and the soundtrack is top notch. According to the credits, it took them 7 years to make this game and it really shows.

But what about the gameplay? Well, the fighting is similar to Shadow of Mordor, but you're pretty much limited to light and heavy attacks with your sword and shield, blocking and rolling away... exactly what you'd expect from a Roman soldier. Executions are satisfying and if you pull them off correctly your health gets replenished. You also get to throw spears and use a scorpion catapult which is lot of fun.

Ultimately, what makes Ryse so good is the story. If you love movies like Gladiator and 300, you'll definitely enjoy Ryse: Son of Rome.

reviewText:
History repeating

It's about as complex as Simon Says, and while it did get repetitive quickly, I'm not going to pretend that I was too sophisticated to derive some pleasure from it for the five hours Ryse lasted. I'm not proud of it, but a childish, depraved part of me enjoyed the shiny graphics and dismemberment every time.

It's essentially the combat from the Batman Arkham and Assassin's Creed games, which means a strong reliance on counters and follow-up strikes. What makes those games so much better than Ryse is that they start with those core mechanics, but then slowly add new gadgets, enemies, and other wrinkles. They have open worlds where I could use that combat to accomplish a bigger goal. Ryse has none of that.

reviewText:
Codename: Kingdoms.
Ryse: The Kinect Game.
?????
Ryse: Son of Rome.

Considering the development hell this game's been through, Crytek deserves some credit in putting the game out.
Ryse is one of the most beautiful games I've played. Simply a stunner.
Unfortunately everything else (gameplay mechanics & story) simply isn't there to captivate the player.
Too much emphasis on QTEs, one-dimensional combat, awkward camera & move set. Lack of freedom is apparent, and this game suffers from the Press A for Awesome Cinematic Game Experience(TM)" syndrome.
Got the game for ~13EUR. For that
date: it's worth playing through. Even to see all the wrongs of modern AAA game approach."

reviewText: Going into Ryse: Son of Rome, I had few expectations for it. I mostly got it because it was on sale. The game is oh so definitely short, 4-5 hours max on hard, five for me due to multiple deaths. There are collectibles to find throughout the world, though I didn't pursue that much. The story isn't great by any stretch and is somewhat forgettable, but it fulfills its purpose. The gameplay was surprisingly not terrible, repetitive yes, but not as much of a QTE-fest as I had expected and the visuals are absolutely dazzling. The online seemed rather dead to me as I waited at least five minutes for a lobby and none showed up. Overall, if you can get this game on sale for a cheap price, I would recommend it as it has enough going for it that it will entertain.

reviewText:
Got it on sale, very impressed with this game.

This has to be some sort of benchmark of beautifulness.  I need a new computer now to play this game in all it's glory.

Gameplay and RPG elements are a little shallow but overall it does shallow very well.  Skill trees only go 4 levels deep (only 3 to unlock) and there's probably only a few types of enemies.  The executions and other special abilities are enough variety to make all the simple rock-paper-scissors gameplay varied every time.

I appreciate that there are secrets to unlock, makes exploring every inch of the landscape worthwhile.

Multiplayer is a nice touch as well, should give the game much more replayability!  The only thing I wish it had more of is breakables. reviewText:
So here I am after a good playthrough with some online gameplay and extensive exploration.

The game has basically the best visuals I ever experienced...it's by cryengine 4 so it already tells a lot. Not only graphically good, but the design of the levels has lots of varieties and an excellent quality. The game is pretty much the whole time on a rail though, so in a sense it was easy to create such a detailed and pleasant scenery.

I think this game is a lot underrated. I know about the problem with colorblind people. I am referring though to the game itself. The combat feels great, you feel every stab, every parry, combined with incredible graphics and animations. Online is also very nice to beat barbarians together with another player (Spartacus arena style :)

The problem is basically that even if the combat is very well made, is the same combat from the beginning till the end. No weapons, not a lot of skills to upgrade, no combos....but well, if you like the first part of the game and you don't get bored after the first 2 hours, it is unlikely that you will not like the rest. I loved the setting and the combat, but I would lie if I did not say that the combat becomes actually boring and repeated to nausea.....

+ incredible graphics and animations
+ great scenery (how many action games do we have in ancient rome???) and level design
+ good combat feeling, challenging enough
+ online multiplayer can be a lot of fun

- combat is good but too repetitive

78/100

reviewText:
P.C. (Price Comparison)

The argument for gaming on a PC rather than a console is a pretty convincing one.
If you’ve got a modern gaming PC it will almost certainly bring more horsepower to the table than its console cousins, of course the down side to this is that a decent gaming PC is also likely to cost a lot more than a “Box of X” or a “Station of Play.”
This price of entry (amongst countless other things) contributes to the current dominance of the consoles.


P.C. (Popular Consoles)

When Little Johnny wants to start “gaming” with his friends, they’ll almost certainly have consoles, so naturally that’s what he’ll want too, which will likely set him on the path of console gamery for the rest of his playing days.
Of course the reason that all his friends have consoles in the first place could be due to the reluctance of “The bank of mom and dad” to fund the cost of a gaming PC when they can pick up a console for half the price.


P.C. (Potential Changes)

As PC gamers, we know this is a short sighted view; you can’t upgrade the guts of your “Wee Station Play Box One”, its technology is static, everyday it becomes a little more obsolete until finally the lifecycle of the console comes to an end and “SoMicronysoft” want you to invest in their new box of tricks.
All the while the PC gamer can continue to stuff new hardware inside his box whenever he feels the need; every day is like a new console release day to a PC owner.


P.C.  (Perfect Choice)

If you’re willing to take the plunge into PC gaming, you’re entering a world of higher frame rates, sharper graphics, continual upgradeability without the need to “throw it out and start again” and a modding community the consoles can only dream of.
If that isn’t enough, look up any recent multiplatform release and I’ll bet the PC version is cheaper than its console counterparts.
These are just some of the reasons why I’m a PC gamer and a proud member of the glorious PC gaming Master Race.
...but I do have a confession to make...


P.C (Personal Confession)

Despite everything I’ve written above, my PC gaming loyalty has been tested and I’m sorry to say I haven’t always been faithful.

I’ve flirted with the Playstation, I’ve spent long weekends with the Xbox, I even had a brief fling with Nintendo (we all make mistakes) but even when those console temptresses were leading me astray with their joy pads I always knew that the PC was the one I was meant to be with, you know, deep down...

Why am I making this confession to you now?

Well, my last act of PC gaming infidelity was the purchase of an Xbox One, It was just so tempting, all those Xbox exclusives whispering “play me now”

...I was weak.

One of those seductive titles happened to be “Ryse Son of Rome.”

Ryse was an Xbox One exclusive launch title and ironically, although being one of the main reasons I bought the console in the first place, was never a game I actually got around to playing.
That is an oversight I’m happy to correct now that the game has finally made its way across to the PC.


P.C. (Port Concerns)

Console ports always make me nervous; we’ve all played rushed conversions which haven’t been optimised properly for the PC.
It can be heartbreaking to see a game running as smooth as butter on your friends console only to have it stutter and lag on your top end computer.
Thankfully Crytek have done a fine job of bringing Rise Son of Rome across to the PC along with some extra content, FPS improvements and enhanced resolution options that most PC gamers expect these days.


P.C. (Pretty Cinematics)

Despite the time that has passed following the release of Ryse on the Xbox, the game is still beautiful to behold, especially on the PC.
Sunlight glints off armour, blood sprays through the air and moody facial expressions are abound.
The locations are equally spectacular, from cliff top outposts to the glory of Rome itself, everything is achingly beautiful to look at.
All of which makes Ryse a great game to watch, but is it fun to play?


P.C. (Problematic Combat)

The combat in Ryse will remind you of the Batman titles, it’s mostly a block and counter affair.
It can be a lot of fun turning a sword aside with your shield and countering with a slicing strike that fells your enemy in a spray of blood.

This block and attack combat mechanic works well and is beautifully animated, which is just as well as you’re going to be seeing an awful lot of it through the 6-8 hours of play time on offer.

By the time you’re a few hours into the game the combat is going to start feeling a little repetitive, nothing new is really injected into the combat as you progress either which is a real shame, something a little different to break up constant doge, attack, dodge button mashing would have been very welcome.


P.C. (Predictable Clichés)

The story itself is quite interesting , in a clichéd but beautifully presented kind of way.
Set during the time of Emperor Nero, you’ll find yourself on a quest for revenge.
A quest which mostly involves charging at the bad guys and killing them.
When the gory blood fest comes to an end you’ll be rewarded with a cut scene to move the story forward a little.

The cut-scenes themselves are well voiced and again superbly animated; there’s even a little interference by some Roman Spirits"  to add a little supernatural spice to the tale which is always welcome.

The game is heavily influenced by movies like Gladiator
date: I half expected Russell Crowe to pop up in a cut scene and give his "Father to a murdered son
recommended:
husband to a murdered wife" vengeance speech.


P.C. (Player Concerns)

My biggest concern with Ryse Son of Rome is that I'm not sure if you'll be motivated enough to finish playing it.
The game play quickly becomes repetitive and the story might not be strong enough to keep you hooked even though the game itself is fairly short.
If you stick with it you’ll be able to finish the 8 chapter single player campaign in a weekend.
There is a multiplayer mode to give it a little extra shelf life if that's your thing.


P.C. (Preferred  Controls)

Whilst you can play Ryse with a mouse and keyboard I would recommend using a controller.
Clicking away with the mouse works perfectly well but this game was designed with the Xbox in mind and a joy pad feels like a much more natural way to control things.


P.C. (Push Characters)

Besides the blocking and attacking controls you can also shove enemies away which will make them temporarily drop their guard
hoursPlayed: you can also pull off "execution" moves by way of a simple colour coded quick time event during battle. This is a neat touch and leads to some pretty gruesome finishing moves.\nUnfortunately
voteText: even these "special" moves begin to feel samey and repetitive as you progress through the game
helpfulPercent:
the fact that most of the barbarians you'll face are cookie cutter enemies and you'll find yourself killing the same character model with the same button presses over and over again really doesn't help.


P.C. (Petty Criticism)

There's a constant deja vu feeling that the rinse and repeat combat mechanics create which only worsens the longer you play.
Having said all that
votesHelpful:
Ryse isn’t a bad game; my expectations were pretty high before playing which probably tainted my experience a little.


P.C. (Pensive Conclusion)

Despite its repetitive game play and it’s by the numbers plot there’s still plenty of entertainment to be found here.
The game does a good job of making you feel like a competent fighter as you slash and hack your way through an almost endless amount of Russell Crowe wannabies .

Visually the game is stunning
votesTotal: I know..... [snip]\n\nFor the full review (and others) please visit http://www.review-well.com/ryse--son-of-rome-review.html"

reviewText:
This piece of virtual enternaiment is a button mashing action game in a completely fictional environment with a couple of actual historical Characters here and there.

If I have understood correctly, this exist as a launch title for X-box one. It is here to showcase the hardware of that system.
Doesn't quite fit with PC though. The graphics are a lot worse if you can't afford a huge gaming computer to waste your life on. It is also quite impossible to play without a controller. An X-box controller would be a fine choise. I don't own any X-box related nonsense myself, so getting used to X-box buttons in a game where spamming the correct buttons in a battle is vital.

The game is quite short. Especially if you sprint through it. It seems to be a heavily cinematic game but everything happened quite quickly so it didn't feel very emmotional. Especially the beginning where the main character loses his parents.

Speaking of the main character, this young fellow Marius is a Roman legionary who magically survives everything and fights several hundreads of Barbarians with his sword that isn't even a Roman sword. He also has a beard, so he might be a Barbarian (Huge plotwist). No, not really but the game is full of such unrealistic facts, objects and actions. So it's a heavily fictional game, not for those who seek to enjoy the experience of our ancestors.

As an X-box launch title it is fine to showcase that console, as a Steam game, not so much.

2.4/5

reviewText:
Got it on sale, very impressed with this game.

This has to be some sort of benchmark of beautifulness.  I need a new computer now to play this game in all it's glory.

Gameplay and RPG elements are a little shallow but overall it does shallow very well.  Skill trees only go 4 levels deep (only 3 to unlock) and there's probably only a few types of enemies.  The executions and other special abilities are enough variety to make all the simple rock-paper-scissors gameplay varied every time.

I appreciate that there are secrets to unlock, makes exploring every inch of the landscape worthwhile.

Multiplayer is a nice touch as well, should give the game much more replayability!  The only thing I wish it had more of is breakables.  There are some obvious pots to smash but 99% of the environment is completely static.  I would love to be able to smash EVERYTHING!!  Or at least kick it around a bit.

reviewText:
After I've seen some gameplay footage a few years back I thought this game would be mediocre at the most, but I must admit, I was wrong.
It's a solid, good game. It has its flaws, but it's also fun. The finishers are bloody, graphics is nice, setting is quite original and music definitely delivers. Additionally, even though the game is short and plot is simple, Marius and Vitallion are memorable characters, mainly due to the pretty good voice acting.
When it comes to the flaws, the game offers very simplistic fight model, low variety of enemy models and bunch of skilles QTEs.
To sum up, if you don't mind Call of Duty-like campaign and QTEs and look for short, bloody game with nice graphics and memorable characters, Ryse son of Rome is a good choice when it's on sale.

reviewText:

The Good:
The fighting isn't hard to pick up and once you've figured it out the execution system is loads of fun. The story is fantastic and the best part of the game in my opinion. Though the game can be short if played simply for the story if you can get it on sale its a must grab.

reviewText:
Short but satisfying.

The single player is good, it had me playing it from beginning to end and enjoying pretty much every minute of it. The story is good, all about vengeance, with excellent voice acting and very nice visuals.

I have not played  any of the multiplayer and probably never will so i can't comment on that, but the single player was the reason i bought this and for the price £5 in a steam sale I couldnt complain at all.

The only issue i had with this game was the annoying fiddly camera moments, which happen every now and then usually during insane combat moments and the awkward cinematic moments when the camera just pans off on its own little side quest :P

Other than the camera the game ran great, and looked amazing. I just needed to be longer, but i will be playing through again on a much harder difficulty because i did find the game a little easy even on the later levels.

7.5/10 - Could of been longer, camera is annoying sometimes, but visuals, voice acting, melee combat were all excellent.

reviewText:
Absolutely gorgeous game, pretty decent storyline, very good fun especially when it comes to multiplayer survival.

The combat feels like someone's crossed a music rhythm / timing game with a brutal hack-and-slash, and I'm personally really digging that. Positioning isn't terribly important and you're not smashing horribly complex button combinations to juggle enemies like you'd expect out of the Devil May Cry series or Metal Gear Rising for example.

You're just left clicking for damage, right clicking to stumble / break guard, space bar for parrying enemy attacks, shift for dodging heavies, and QTEing executions. Targeting is completely automatic. On paper it sounds pretty disappointing, but when you're nailing down the timing on everything, building up 90x+ combos with a perfect chain and executing enemies with legendary timing, it just makes you smile.

Very satisfying.

reviewText:
First off im a total Rome fanatic, so of course I was going to get this game when I heard it was coming out to PC. This game is bassically the spiritual successor of one of my favorite games, Spartan Total Warrior. It feels wonderfully familiar while at the same time feeling fresh. The controls are a bit to get use to at first but after about a good ten to fifteen minutes you start to comfortably get the hang of it. The graphics speak for themselves of course (Crytek always does an amazing job with their graphics) But what is great is that you can set the graphics quality to low and still get beautiful vistas, detailed soldiers and environments what have you. the art of this game is just magnificent as well from the large Crytek vistas to the little details like grafitti on the walls of buildings.

This game I can already tell though will suffer from repetivness rather quickly. The combat while feeling cinematic the whole way through will begin to stale as the game seems to be obsessed with kill moves. You dont have to finish every enemy with kill moves but it really doesnt make sense not to use them at the same time as that can just drag out fights. The story I can see will be short and sweet one as well. Which is a bit of shame seeing this is Cryteks first real action game, I feel the campaign can be longer already but on the plus side the Arena will help in justifying the price tag as you fight through wave after wave of enemies.

So overall, its a beautiful game, fun gameplay though it will get stale, a story that will most likely be too short but from what I see right now of it is pretty entertaining. And a multiplayer mode that if players take advantage of it will most likely prove to be a fun little alternative to anyone looking for a bit of a different experience, is it worth the $40 price tag? That is more or less up to you, I say yes but im already biased to the type of game this is and its setting. But anyone taht is on the fence should probably wait for it go on sale first.

The only true shame of the game is it never came with a demo, it is a bit of hefty game, and for anyone that is on the fence about getting it that would have definetly given them the most informed decision.

reviewText:
Ryse comes to PC after launching on Xbox One with mixed reception. Before anything else, this game looks gorgeous from both an artistic and graphical stand-point. Its rendition of ancient Rome, while perhaps not entirely accurate, looks great. The brutal executions that you perform while a mind-numbing large amount of debilitations make the mid-combat executions feel extremely satisfying.

That is, however, where the praises end. Enemy variety seems shockingly low. Granted, I haven't reached the end yet; but, I found the same bearded fat man with a shield about 20 times in the first 0 minutes of the game. Why is it that only bearded barbarians can hold a shield? I didn't look too closely, but I felt that the other throw-away enemies were also lacking in variety. I'm pretty sure, they have less faces and models than Rome Total War 2.

Game-play feels relatively responsive, although the auto-aim for the javelins make ranged combat somewhat annoying. Execuations can be done for various bonuses and is also the only way to heal.  These make you invulnerable and proceed to give you a series of button prompts. Regardless of whether you hit the right buttons or not, the execution will happen. These look great both early and late game, but you will soon get bogged down with execution after execution until you just want to take a quick break during the sequence.

The story is vaguely reminiscent of the Gladiator movie with some supernatural twists. Voice acting and cut-scenes were well done although quite forgettable. Overall, this game is a 3/5 for me. It looks great when you first dig into it; but once the glamour fades away, all that's left is a shell of a game.

reviewText:
So I started off watching videos of this on Youtube taken from the Xbox and thought wow this looks cool. It should be epic on the PC etc etc. So I went against my better judgement and pre ordered the game.

Today is release day so after work i've booted it up and started hacking a few barbarians to bits. It started off quite well graphics are looking like a Thai lady boy after a few too many jars of ale, running it across my 3 screens I noticed the FPS was about as low as a ♥♥♥♥♥s knickers in Soho.

Fair enough its fresh out the virtual box drivers not been updated for it I will drop it down to the one screen and see how it looks. Expecting a earth shattering result like the 44.7% unrealistic scottish folk in the recent independence vote i was like them given a shift kick in the knackers and brought back down to earth with a bit of a bump.

FPS barely breaking double figures I did a bit more tickering and managed to up it to 45 FPS. How my mouth frothed at the prospect of some semi smooth limb chopping...

Off we go again on our wee bloodfest. Over the bridge defend the wall fire the scorpion - which ran smoother on 3 screens than it did on the one which i found quite tickling. So now i'm into the Palace met that fat pie eating chump called Nero and started to hold his hand and lead him to safety.

We boot open a door into a large chamber down some steps to fight some more rabid blue painted lunitics who look chillingly similar to a family that live round the corner from me. We exchange blows have a few hugs and kisses and eventually i am overcome by the shear armoa of they unwashed vermin from round the corner.

So another go is attempted. I restart charge into the room doing my finest Mel Gibson Braveheart impression to find the room empty. Ah-ha my blue faced warbling screaming must of made the great unwashed flee for their lives.
Right onto the next room, i run to the stairs full belt and stop!

I can't progress any further. I can now neither go up the steps out of the room or back up the steps I orgininally came down.

Stuck in a very nice room with a lovely water feature with no fat emperor or a horde of great unwashed...

This ladies and gentleman is Ryse: Son of Rome.............

I have seen less bugs in an ant hill

Terrible just absolutley terrible and to think i even painted my face blue before i started playing this. Should of just done my nails instead...

reviewText:
Bought it in a sale, I've completed it on Centurion and played half way through the Legendary difficulty. The game has positive elements, the facial animation and use of facial animation during combat is especially impressive. The campaign is reasonably enjoyable albeit a hackneyed mash up of Rome / Gladiator and every other modern day TV representation of the Roman Era. The voice acting and real actor involvement in the story was well done.

What will spoil the experience for many is the actual game engine, specifically performance on some setups. It's all over the place. From 60fp, to 40fps, to 1fps in the space of a contextual execution. My library to date includes 2300+ games not including gaming platforms outside of Steam. This is as flaky as it gets, completely random and playing around with the settings makes nowhere near the impact which it should on performance as its not a hardware issue, it's quite clearly the game engine. Community hub is littered with similar complaints from people running the game on 970s & 980s and theres an absolute lack of support or acknowledgement of the issue.....

and for that very reason I wouldn't recommend the game to anyone.

Especially frustrating here as the PC in question runs Arkham Knight at steady 30-60 fps with all gameworks settings and everything else maxed bar a few AA / AF settings, and has no performance issues with Crysis 3.

reviewText: Let me start by saying that this game is absolutely beautiful. Graphically, it's a solid 10/10. The story, while slightly uninspired, is interesting enough to keep you moving through missions, but nothing you'll remember fondly. That said, the combat mechanics are quite dull after about an hour, and I found myself frequently shutting the game down, going to do something else to quell my boredom, and coming back later. As far as 'ranged' combat goes, I can honestly say that it is one of the most frustrating and broken mechanics I have ever seen in a game. On the topic of broken mechanics, you will often have Roman soldiers following you during missions, and as often as they are following you they will do absolutely nothing to help you. I often found myself fighting 6 or 8 enemies at a time while I had 8+ Romans following me. Fighting high volumes of enemies, being unable to break combat with them, having NPCs that do nothing to help, and being told that you need to fight a specific enemy in a small timeframe or fail your mission ultimately results in assured failure, and aggravating restarts.\n\nI had very high hopes for this game, and I am dissapointed. Poorly designed and implemented mechanics galore, useless NPCs, and repetitive enemies all make for an experiance that can be summarized simply as 'irritating'.

reviewText:
I think that this game is a little confused. I think it wants to be a movie. It starts really well, the game is fun for about 45 minutes (a friend and I were taking turns) but then repeats its self relentlessly.
The graphics are outstanding and being able to murderise people in extravagantly brutal ways is fun, at first.

The major drawbacks of this game are
*Ridiculously long cut scenes which can not be skipped or paused, and personally they're pretty boring.
*Every single execution is a quick time event and there are entirely too many quick time events.
*Different game play mechanics are not revealed through the game. Once you have played for 30-45 mins you will have had everything the game has to offer. Infact just get the demo, if available.
*Too many quick time events.
*Its so linear that at some points, all you need to do is hold down forward! Seriously unimpressive.
*The story is long, predictable, boring and just how did the Britians get to Rome to sack it in the first place? Was the rest of the Roman empire asleep? Anyway, not a fan of Hollywood style history.
*The long boring story is unskipable.
*Did I mention the QTE's?

I would definitely recommend that you spend your hard earnt money on a different game.

X:)

reviewText:
Bought this game on sale for $19.99 and it was still about 15 dollars too much.

Pros: Just like everyone else I will admit the game is beautiful, the dialog is great, and overall you can tell a lot of time and effort was spent designing this game.

Cons: 20 bucks to play a game for 6 hours with almost no replay value is not my idea of a deal. I feel bad for anyone who buys it at 40 or more. The game is unbelievably linear with no real drive to do anything than to hit essentially 4 buttons 96% of the time.

Summary: Beautiful game that excites me about future games from a graphical standpoint but it just completely misses on the gameplay. Grab it for 5 bucks in another 6 months to a year on a steam sale and enjoy yourself then.

reviewText: Ever wanted to play as a Roman Centurion and lay waste to barbarians? Well, this is the game to get it done. Featuring unbelievably life like graphics, solid combat and blood aplenty this game is an amazing example of what to do right when porting a game to pc. It's solid. In my playtime I've encountered absolutely no bugs yet and the combat is meaty and well done. Executions are ripping and bone jarring and every hit has a solid impact. If you're looking for a great game with great combat definitely give this a try. I don't think you'll regret it.

reviewText:
I've finished Ryse: Son of Rome three times now. Twice on Xbox One and once on PC. The game is definitely good, but has some very glaring flaws, especially the PC version, but more on that later.
This game looks absolutely stunning, without a doubt it is one of the best looking games ever made. The combat is brutal and satisfying, if a bit repetitious. The voice acting and animation are good.
The story however barely makes any sense. It's just plain bad. Also the game is REALLY short, it only takes about 5 hours from start to finish. And as for the optimization on PC... my system meets the recommendations (AMD FX-6350 @ 3.9GHz, 8GB RAM, R9 280) and the game really runs like ♥♥♥♥. It's constantly dipping under 30fps, which is almost unplayable. None of the graphics settings make much of an effect on the framerate, which leads me to believe that this game is VERY CPU heavy. All AMD users should beware before spending 40€ on this one. I'd say wait for a sale unless you have a powerful Intel CPU.

Even though I like the game alot, I cannot recommend a game that is this poorly optimized on the PC.

PS. Having later upgraded my PSU, Mobo, CPU (i5-4690) and GPU (GTX 980 Ti) it seems that this problem has nothing to do with CPU or even GPU. For some reason (at least if you're an Nvidia user) you HAVE to have Shadowplay ON in order for the game to run smoothly. What the hell, Crytek? I can only surmise this has something to do with the game being originally and Xbox One exclusive and Xbox One constantly records gameplay. Somehow having Shadowplay recording your gameplay on PC it fixes the horrible stuttering. Silky smooth now.

reviewText:
Terrible port from the XBox
Game is ridiculously short, it is only 8 missions long, and they're all pretty much the exact same format, I beat this game is only a few hours, and I'm not that good of a gamer.

There are literally only 5 types of enemies, and to defeat them you just need to learn the 3-4 button sequence required to break their block and kill them. The hot buttons are ridiculous, they give you colours but don't tell you what they mean. controls are awkward and the involuntary locking onto enemies is too hard set, not to mention sometimes you are locked into combat with 4-5 enemies but randomly start attacking the ground beside them.  If you get someone pinned in a corner so they cannot move, but you stray outside that 3-4 button sequence, they'll dodge your strikes without actually moving.  It's even the exact same thing for bosses, you just need to learn their button sequence and repeat until they are dead.

The idea and especially the setting had promise, but the plot ended up being utterly ludicrous and stupid.

On the plus side, the graphics are really good, though they put all their effort into molding the 3-4 main male characters, the female characters are all just second rate. They put all their effort into modelling their breasts (which are always hanging out) and totally forgot about the rest of their bodies.  The characters themselves were so one-dimensional, I don't know why they put so much effort into modelling them realistically when they act like cartoons.

1/10

reviewText: Beautiful graphics, cool story, but atrocious repeatitive gameplay coupled with an uninteresting timing based combat system. Each level has the same layout: Enter area fight a horde of same enemies in different skins until they are all dead; move to next area fight horde of enemies until they are dead; issue an abitrary command to some soldiers; defend area where soldiers aren't; walk with soldiers in a shield wall to next area; fight a few waves then a boss; rinse wash repeat. This would be okay if the game hadn't shipped at $59. I'd rather buy gauntlet for $19 do the same thing but at least have more variety and customization. This game would have been better as movie. It's not worth $39 or $59. Watch a Let's Play on Youtube if you really care about the story.

reviewText:
Solely based on singleplayer
Pros:
+Pleasing combat finishers
+Clean and smooth melee with multiple enemies
+Beautiful graphics and particle effects (in general)
+Nice idea for a storyline
+Some incorporated historical aspects

Cons:
-Sporadic FPS drops on a PC well above the min. spec.
--Especially on one mission where it was like a powerpoint presentation
-Very difficult melee concept to grasp
-Very high player health stats means you can just left click through 90% of enemies
-In general lacked historical accuracy
-Expensive game for what is essentially 6/7 hours of gameplay (This is why I wouldn't reccomend)

reviewText:
If you are like me, then you have had a boyhood fascination with romans ever since you first saw Russel Crowe and his decidedly dodgy fringe, hacking up bad guys in the film Gladiator. If your like me you slavered over the stunning visuals that Ryse, son of Rome boasts, and couldn't wait to buy the game and dive head first into the historical, fantastical action.
I did just that and despite the gaming living up to the hype as far as graphics and voiceacting were concerned, it left me feeling somewhat deflated.

Firsty, let me just say that I really, really really wanted this game to be good. the Cinematic nature appealed to me when I first saw the trailer and I have to admit, the assassin's creed style, press and watch, style of combat was very cool. For the first hour or so. Unfortunately, stunning visuals, and they are stunning by the way, did very little to distract me from what felt like a very rushed, flat storyline.

The protagonist worked well as a character, but his story arc was as bland as the art designer's choice of enemy types. The words copy and paste can't help but spring to mind after hacking down your fiftieth enemy who bears more than a striking resemblance to the last guy that tried to kill you.

The game just is not long enough either. I completed the campaign in around three hours, and although the developers clearly idended a sort of  gears of war esque co-op system for the multiplayer, it doesnt really provide any incentive to make you actually play with other people. You can literally do the whole thing yourself.

Finally. My biggest gripe with this game was how shockingly innacurate it was historically. I must have missed the part in my history books at school where Boudica led a grand invasion of Rome from the back of one of Hannibals war elephants, which he had kindly lent to her for the weekend.

All in all this game promises a lot but delivers very little. Its redeeming features are few and far between and even if bashing your head aganst hordes of identical siblings for fun is your thing; Dynasty warriors fans i'm looking at you, you would be hard pressed not to be annoyed at Ryse son of Rome.

To buy or not to buy? That may be the question you are considering and the choice is of course your own, but if i were looking for a cool, visually stunning game with romans in I'd buy Skyrim, play as an imperial and try my best to ignore the Dragons.

Happy Gaming.

reviewText: I bought this game on 66% sale for $13.xx at that price or less it is an ok buy. Campaign is repetitive and too short which seems odd to say, but I found the campaign not long enough and basically the same hack and slash fight over and over again. Graphics are stunning, story is ok. There could have been so many great things had this game attmepted to tackle them. I yearned for something more in the Coliseum. I ranked multiplayer 1v1 battle add on would be pretty amazing. They game feels rushed. Co-op multiplayer i boring and more of the same repeat. Why anyone would play it for an extended period I do not not know. If you are ok with putting about 10 hours into this game and never picking it up again it's fine. Replayability is 0 in my opinion.

reviewText: Ok, so is that it? Is this the future of beat 'em up/ hack n' slash games inherited by the post-God of War generation? What a drawback. The graphics, the sound FX and the animations are superb... But the combos don't feel rewarding, the difficulty ain't challenging, the game is very linear and present you with no choices at all... The camera is glitchy and sometimes it repositions itself on its own after an execution scene. The game lacks enemy models, you're gonna picture yourself fighting against familiar faces all the time, sometimes a whole wave of foes is composed of clones, hahaha. The multiplayer is only co-op for two players and looks destined to die away soon, so the single player campaing is all you got. Cheesus... Ain't worthy the full price, I've got it at 50% because of Summer Sale and still feel robbed. Also, the game fills 25 Gb of disk space. So much space for an average game. Overall, its so-so, I'd give it a 5.5/10 thus I can't really recommend it.

reviewText:
tl;dr: Only buy this game if 1: you have too much money on your hands 2: it's like 90% off 3: you don't mind dull gameplay as long as the graphics are shiny.

Anyway.

Pros:
+ Graphics (they really are pretty - watch out if you have an older GPU because the game will not be kind to it)
+ Voice acting (the cast took their job seriously and it shows)

Cons:
- Awful story (I'm not saying that I can't enjoy a classic revenge story but this one was so chichéd that it felt like it was working from a checklist)
- Uninteresting characters that you don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about
- Simplistic, boring, repetitive battles with constant QTE finishers (no, there aren't button prompts but enemies will flash blue or yellow depending on whether you have to press X or Y which is pretty much the same)
- Complete lack of challenge - you can pretty much play this game with one hand while you're browsing Facebook on your phone. The lack of attack variety from enemies is quite painful - there's an advanced" enemy that literally has one - ONE! - type of attack
date: a 4x unblockable combo that you have to dodge around. That's all it can do. Speaking of variety - enemies are pretty boring too. You get the basic mook with an axe or something
recommended: a big guy with a shield

- Simplistic, boring, repetitive battles with constant QTE finishers (no, there aren't button prompts but enemies will flash blue or yellow depending on whether you have to press X or Y which is pretty much the same)
- Complete lack of challenge - you can pretty much play this game with one hand while you're browsing Facebook on your phone. The lack of attack variety from enemies is quite painful - there's an advanced" enemy that literally has one - ONE! - type of attack

reviewText:
This game fails at exactly ONE thing:

The control scheme.

Let me explain.

No key rebinding for game pads. In 2014.
Also, you can no longer disable force feedback ( with a game pad) , and it's not even provided as an option.
And finally, for what it's worth, omitting such basic elementary options and then not providing workarounds to them is a big omission , one that cannot go unnoticed.

And this is the only reason I ask for refunds:

Devs, stick true to common sense. Controller customization and toggles for force feedback are staple.
Don't mess with my controllers and basic options, and we're good,

♥♥♥♥ that up,and it will NOT be overlooked in the slightest.

reviewText:
If you are like me, then you have had a boyhood fascination with romans ever since you first saw Russel Crowe and his decidedly dodgy fringe, hacking up bad guys in the film Gladiator. If your like me you slavered over the stunning visuals that Ryse, son of Rome boasts, and couldn't wait to buy the game and dive head first into the historical, fantastical action.
I did just that and despite the gaming living up to the hype as far as graphics and voiceacting were concerned, it left me feeling somewhat deflated.

Firsty, let me just say that I really, really really wanted this game to be good. the Cinematic nature appealed to me when I first saw the trailer and I have to admit, the assassin's creed style, press and watch, style of combat was very cool. For the first hour or so. Unfortunately, stunning visuals, and they are stunning by the way, did very little to distract me from what felt like a very rushed, flat storyline.

The protagonist worked well as a character, but his story arc was as bland as the art designer's choice of enemy types. The words copy and paste can't help but spring to mind after hacking down your fiftieth enemy who bears more than a striking resemblance to the last guy that tried to kill you.

The game just is not long enough either. I completed the campaign in around three hours, and although the developers clearly idended a sort of  gears of war esque co-op system for the multiplayer, it doesnt really provide any incentive to make you actually play with other people. You can literally do the whole thing yourself.

Finally. My biggest gripe with this game was how shockingly innacurate it was historically. I must have missed the part in my history books at school where Boudica led a grand invasion of Rome from the back of one of Hannibals war elephants, which he had kindly lent to her for the weekend.

All in all this game promises a lot but delivers very little. Its redeeming features are few and far between and even if bashing your head aganst hordes of identical siblings for fun is your thing; Dynasty warriors fans i'm looking at you, you would be hard pressed not to be annoyed at Ryse son of Rome.

To buy or not to buy? That may be the question you are considering and the choice is of course your own, but if i were looking for a cool, visually stunning game with romans in I'd buy Skyrim, play as an imperial and try my best to ignore the Dragons.

Happy Gaming.

reviewText: I bought this game on 66% sale for $13.xx at that price or less it is an ok buy. Campaign is repetitive and too short which seems odd to say, but I found the campaign not long enough and basically the same hack and slash fight over and over again. Graphics are stunning, story is ok. There could have been so many great things had this game attmepted to tackle them. I yearned for something more in the Coliseum. I ranked multiplayer 1v1 battle add on would be pretty amazing. They game feels rushed. Co-op multiplayer i boring and more of the same repeat. Why anyone would play it for an extended period I do not not know. If you are ok with putting about 10 hours into this game and never picking it up again it's fine. Replayability is 0 in my opinion.

reviewText: Ok, so is that it? Is this the future of beat 'em up/ hack n' slash games inherited by the post-God of War generation? What a drawback. The graphics, the sound FX and the animations are superb... But the combos don't feel rewarding, the difficulty ain't challenging, the game is very linear and present you with no choices at all... The camera is glitchy and sometimes it repositions itself on its own after an execution scene. The game lacks enemy models, you're gonna picture yourself fighting against familiar faces all the time, sometimes a whole wave of foes is composed of clones, hahaha. The multiplayer is only co-op for two players and looks destined to die away soon, so the single player campaing is all you got. Cheesus... Ain't worthy the full price, I've got it at 50% because of Summer Sale and still feel robbed. Also, the game fills 25 Gb of disk space. So much space for an average game. Overall, its so-so, I'd give it a 5.5/10 thus I can't really recommend it.

reviewText:
I pretty much can only echo the more mediocre reviews for this game.

Pros:
* Graphics, omg so pretty

Cons:
* Boring gameplay, very repetitive. The final boss battle is basically kill this guy, now kill 6 copies of him, now kill 6 copies of him in the fog, now kill him again.
* Controls offered very little control with heavy reliance on overly simplistic quick time events
* While gorgeous, the world was full of artificial barriers resulting in an impressively linear story with very little player engagement
* Skill tree is mostly meaningless and basically comes down to the ability to have a wider of variety of kill animations. I did not 100% the skill tree, tho I got close but this was because i had absolutely no incentive to do so.
* Short, I got over it in about 6 hours  and only died like once. While it may seem like a mercy that it was short given my complaints above I had a secret hope that it was just getting going and might unlock some deeper gameplay elements when I had mastered the basic character stats, this was not to be.

In short, the only reasons I kept playing till the end was the faint hope it would improve. (and the graphics, omg gorgeous)

Money back please, I should have waited til it was on sale. :(

reviewText:
Ryse is visual eye candy but that's about it. The entire game is on rails with bosses that can be defeated fairly easily once one gets the timing down. Each enemy is the same. There is no variation. The most fun is when you're in formation with the troops and have to use either spears or shield wall to deal with the obstacles but even this becomes boring after a while.

Basically, this is the game for the kind of guy who wants a trophy wife.

It's visually stunning but there's really not that much beneath the surface.

It's short too. Even playing it on the 3rd difficulty setting it took me just a few hours to fly through. Glad I waited for it to be on sale and didn't end up buying it full price.
